Sharks have multiple rows of teeth and can lose thousands in their lifetime.
Some sharks glow in the dark using biofluorescence.
The Greenland shark can live up to 400 years!
Sharks can detect one part of blood in 100 million parts of water.
Sharks have no bones â€” their skeletons are made of cartilage.
The skin of a shark feels like sandpaper due to tiny tooth-like scales.
Great white sharks can detect electrical fields emitted by prey.
Sharks do not have swim bladders and must keep swimming to breathe.
